Power supply and polarization testing (120V checks)
chapters.content:
Chapter 1 covers the installation, types, features, and code requirements for gas-fired domestic ranges.

TYPES OF GAS RANGES:

1. FREE-STANDING RANGES:
Free-standing means they are not built-in or permanently installed. Most residential service gas-fired ranges are 24 to 30 in wide, free-standing units with integral oven.

2. BUILT-IN RANGES:
Built-in ranges are permanently installed as part of kitchen cabinetry. A gas-fired wall oven is separate built-in unit installed and operated independently from drop-in countertop cooktop unit.

3. GAS AND ELECTRIC COMBINATION UNITS:
Gas and electric combination units offer gas stove top burners with electric oven options.

4. DUAL FUEL UNITS:
Dual fuel gas ranges can run on propane or natural gas. Conversion is usually accomplished by means of adjustable orifice.

MAJOR FEATURES OF GAS RANGES:

SELF-CLEANING FEATURE:
An oven equipped with self-cleaning feature incinerates baked-on dirt in oven by heating to high temperature during cleaning cycle. For safety, oven door locks when cleaning cycle is selected and remains locked until oven cools after cleaning cycle ends.

CONTINUOUS CLEANING FEATURE:
In continuous cleaning oven, dirt is baked off oven surfaces on continuous basis while food is cooking.

BROILER:
Gas stoves formerly utilized oven burner to broil food. Lower drawer was opened to allow same oven burner to serve as broiler burner. Now, gas-fired ovens come with separate broiler units. Broiler is special burner located on top of oven. Heat from burner is directed downward towards food for broiling.

WARMING DRAWER:
Some gas-fired ovens also have warming drawers, which maintain cooked food at desired serving temperature.

HEAT TRANSFER METHODS:

The three methods of heat transfer in cooking appliances are convection, conduction, and radiation.

1. CONVECTION:
Transfer of heat by heat currents. Ovens use one of two methods:

NATURAL CONVECTION OVEN:
Warm air rises and cool air descends. In standard, natural convection oven, hottest area is at top of oven and coolest is at bottom, no matter where burner is located. Thermostats can control burner on-off cycle within certain temperature range, but temperature may vary as much as 50°F from one area of oven to another. This makes it difficult to cook food evenly.

FORCED CONVECTION OVEN:
In forced convection oven, fan circulates heat from burner evenly throughout oven. Circulating heat cooks food faster and more evenly than natural convection oven.

2. CONDUCTION:
Transfer of heat through direct contact. Example: pot of water on rangetop burner being heated through direct contact with burner flame.

3. RADIATION:
Transfer of heat by means of heat rays emitted from heat source. Overhead broiler burner employs this method.

INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:

Before installing gas-fired range, review:
- Manufacturer specifications
- Applicable codes
- Installation instructions

MANUFACTURER SPECIFICATIONS:
Found on model and serial number identification plate (rating plate) attached to appliance at factory. Rating plate includes:
- Input rating (Btu/h or kW)
- Approval by regulating authorities and agencies
- Operating voltage and current
- Operating pressure

INPUT RATING:
Input rating of appliance in Btu/h (or kW) is stamped on rating plate. Rating plate specifications allow appliance installer to determine correct pipe or tubing size for service and set burner inputs correctly.

APPROVALS:
Gas industry and governmental regulatory agencies must approve all gas appliances before manufacturer can sell them. Official logo, symbol, or seal indicating certification appears on rating plate. Certification symbols that must appear on rating plate of gas appliance sold in Canada include those of CSA Group.

OPERATING VOLTAGE AND CURRENT:
Range must only be connected to electrical circuit that conforms to operating voltage and current rating specified on identification plate. Although older gas stoves with few options could function with just gas supply hookup, most gas stoves require 110-V supply outlet to power clocks, ignition sources, programmable features, and oven lighting.

OPERATING PRESSURE:
Gas supply pressure is normally higher than that required for burner operation. Appliance pressure regulator is used to reduce supply pressure to manifold pressure required at burner and maintain it at that level.

Important to maintain correct manifold pressure setting to avoid:
- Delayed ignition
- Sooting
- Flashback
- Extinction pop
- Damage to components
- Poor operating efficiency
- Limit cycling

TYPICAL PRESSURES:
- Inlet to appliance regulator: 7 in w.c. (1.5 kPa) natural gas, 11 in w.c. (2.7 kPa) propane
- Outlet (manifold) pressure: 3.5 to 5 in w.c. (0.9 to 1.25 kPa) natural gas, 10 in w.c. (2.5 kPa) propane

Regulator is usually pre-adjusted for use with type of gas specified on rating plate and for specific outlet pressure. Many ranges come with regulator that is adjustable for use with propane or natural gas. If you are to use range with different gas, adjust regulator accordingly by changing position of simple converter fitting (reversing cap or spring and disc assembly) on regulator.

IMPORTANT: Measure inlet pressure to appliance while it is firing at its rated input. If appliance is not firing, input pressure reading will be static. Static reading does not reflect pressure loss that results from gas flowing through system.

Input pressure to appliance is measured with manometer or pressure gauge installed in tee fitting in supply line just before appliance.

CODE REQUIREMENTS:
All range installations must conform to requirements of applicable building, gas, and electrical codes.

ELECTRICAL CONNECTIONS:
Most gas ranges require electricity to power clocks, timers, and other control devices. Electrical connection is usually 120V, 60Hz, two-wire, and with ground. Minimum size and type of wire that can be used for 120-V, 15-A indoor appliance is No. 14 AWG NMD-90.

All electrical connections between appliance and building wiring must comply with applicable electrical codes. Connection of all electrical devices associated with appliance must follow manufacturer wiring diagram.

Range must be connected to electrical circuit receptacle by means of approved power supply cord with three-prong grounding plug. Extension cords may not be used.

IMPORTANT: Under no circumstances should grounding prong of power supply cord be removed or replaced with two-prong plug or adapter.

PIPING CONNECTIONS:
Code requirements for gas range piping and tubing connections can be found in CSA B149.1, Clause 6.

Rigid piping or flexible connectors may be used to connect ranges to gas supply. Metal (flexible) connectors must be installed in accordance with following code requirements:

- Connectors must be protected from potential damage
- Connectors must not pass through walls, floors, ceilings, or partitions
- Connectors must be connected to rigid pipe or tubing in same area as appliance, with shut-off valve located in same room as appliance
- Gas-fired appliance (range) must not be installed or operated in any location where it could create hazard
- Gas-fired appliance (range) must not be installed in room where corrosive vapours may damage appliance or its venting system

PROHIBITED PRACTICES:
Following practices are prohibited for gas piping installations:
- Defective sections of pipe or tubing must be replaced and not repaired
- Bushings must not be nested (installed within one another)
- Fittings with both left- and right-hand threads, thread protectors, or running threads must not be used
- Concealed piping runs must not contain union or combination of fittings intended to act as swing joint
- Field bending of piping is not permitted
- Gas piping and tubing must not be used as electrical ground
- Piping and tubing must not be used in lieu of electrical wiring, except for low-voltage control circuit, ignition circuit, or flame-detection device circuit incorporated into appliance
- Piping must not contain street elbow or street tee

FLEXIBLE METAL CONNECTORS:
To provide for movement of gas range in order to clean behind it, use certified flexible metal gas connector as final connection to manifold. Not proper practice to expect this level of movement to be accommodated for in loop of copper tubing supply. Certified flexible metal connectors are tested and certified for multiple bends and expansion.

May use flexible metal connectors to connect appliances that may be subject to vibration, expansion, contraction, or other movements that might damage or loosen rigid connection.

FLEXIBLE CONNECTOR CONDITIONS:
- Length of connector must not exceed 6 ft (2m)
- When used to connect appliance to rigid piping, shut-off valve must be installed in piping immediately upstream of flexible connector
- Gas valve must be in same room as gas-fired equipment, and connector must not be concealed within or run through any wall, floor, or partition
- When commercial equipment is on rollers or wheels, it requires restraining cable 25mm shorter than flexible connector

Flexible connectors certified for use on commercial ranges that are moved regularly for cleaning have additional outer protective coverings of stainless-steel braided wire and antimicrobial PVC coating. They also have swivel connections to further reduce stress at ends.

FACILITATING REPAIRS:
Things that can be done during initial installation to make future repairs easier:
- Install flexible connector to allow movement of appliance
- Install shut-off valve upstream and as close to appliance as practical
- Install quick-disconnect device attached to flexible connector (not permitted for use indoors in residential building as per CSA B149.1, Clause 6.11.3)
- Install restraining cable with clips for removal that only get removed after gas has been shut off and connector disconnected

GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS:

SPECIFIC INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:
- Compliance with clearance to combustibles requirements
- Access for cleaning, repairs, and servicing
- Proper distance to venting hoods, flues, or ductwork
- Proper positioning with respect to adjacent cabinets, countertops, and other appliances

IMPORTANT: Never install range in bedroom because it might produce carbon monoxide (CO). However, you may install it in bed-sitting room if you will not use it as space heating appliance (CSA B149.1, Clause 7.33.1).

LEVELLING:
If range is not levelled, fluids will not fill cooking containers properly. This may lead to overflow and spillage that could create fire or personal injury hazard.

ANTI-TIPPING DEVICES:
Some ranges may come with anti-tipping devices. These devices, installed at time of installation, prevent accidental tipping of range. Devices may consist of chain connecting range to wall bracket or rigid bracket attached to back of range and secured to wall behind it.

CLEARANCE TO COMBUSTIBLES:
Different types of ranges have different clearance requirements. Storage cabinets and other combustibles must be installed at safe distance above cooking top of range, while rear and sidewalls of range may be approved for zero clearance.

Manufacturer instructions and rating plate specify approved clearance to combustibles distance for appliance. When not covered in manufacturer instructions or on rating plate, follow appliance clearance requirements found in Code, Clause 7. For example, if not specified by manufacturer, range would require minimum of 150mm of clearance on its back and sides from combustible surfaces.

Combustible cabinets or walls located next to range cooking surface must be protected with 28 MSG (metal sheet gauge) metal shield, spaced out 0.25 in (6mm) from combustible surface and extending from 5 in (125mm) below to 30 in (750mm) above cooking surface.

ZERO CLEARANCE RANGE REQUIREMENTS (CSA B149.1, Clause 7.33.5):

- COMBUSTIBLES ABOVE: No combustibles within 30 in (750mm) of top of range
- COMBUSTIBLE SURFACE REDUCTION: Combustible surfaces protected by shield of 0.25 in (6mm) millboard covered with 28 GSG (0.3mm) sheet metal may be within 24 in (600mm) of top of range
- SPACE BETWEEN BACK: At least 1-in (25mm) space between back of range and combustible surface

POWER SUPPLY AND POLARIZATION:
Ranges equipped with electric components require power supply cord with three-prong grounded plug. Check manufacturer instructions for correct type and size of wire-and-plug assembly.

Range receptacle must be properly grounded. Following simple check confirms whether range is connected safely:

1. Use voltmeter set to measure AC volts. Check voltage across line and neutral conductors at range receptacle. Meter should read 120V, ±10%.
2. Next, check voltage across line and ground conductors. Meter should read 120V.
3. Finally, check voltage across neutral and ground conductors. Meter should read 0V.

Readings that differ from above indicate that circuit or receptacle wiring is incorrect or defective and must be corrected before range is installed.

FUEL CONVERSION:
Conversion from one fuel to another may be required for number of reasons. For example:
- Natural gas may become available in area previously serviced only by propane
- Natural-gas appliance may be purchased for use in area where only propane is available

Three common types of gas pressure regulators exist, each with different method for converting from one gas to another. Important to ensure that appliance regulator is adjusted to operate with gas being used.

Foil duct tape prohibited (use cloth mesh)
No connection to other appliance vents
Exhaust hood termination (12 in/300mm above ground)
Maximum exhaust system length (elbows reduce length)
Drum seal defects (loss of negative pressure)
Door switch, timer motor, drive motor
Glow-coil ignition (transformer, warp switch, warp switch heater)
Warp switch operation (3.5-4 min glow time)
Three-point test for switches and loads
Blower assembly and lint trap blockage
chapters.content:
Chapter 2 covers installation, operation, and servicing of gas-fired clothes dryers.

CLEARANCE TO COMBUSTIBLES:
If there are no manufacturer rating plate clearances, allowable code clearances to combustibles from top, back, and sides of domestic gas dryer are 6 in (150mm).

FLEXIBLE METAL CONNECTORS:
Maximum length of metal connector used to connect gas dryer is 6 ft (2.0m). Same requirements apply as with ranges - connector must be protected from damage, not pass through walls/floors/ceilings, and shut-off valve must be in same room.

MOISTURE EXHAUST DUCT REQUIREMENTS:
- Use cloth mesh duct tape to connect dryer moisture-exhaust duct joints (NOT foil duct tape or electrical tape)
- Three evenly spaced sheet metal screws can also be used
- Moisture exhaust duct CANNOT be connected to another gas appliance vent connector to create common vent
- Exhaust hood must terminate 12 in (300mm) above ground level
- Minimum exhaust vent diameter is 4 in (100mm)

MAXIMUM EXHAUST SYSTEM LENGTH:
Maximum length of exhaust system is determined by:
- Type of exhaust hood
- Type of vent material
- Number of elbows

Each elbow reduces maximum allowable length.

DRYER OPERATION:

DRUM ROTATION:
Drum rotates at between 47 and 50 rpm. Engineering studies have shown this is optimum range for drying contents of dryer.

IF drum turns faster: Clothes are pressed against outside of drum and do not tumble
IF drum turns slower: Clothes ball up in drum

In both cases, drying times are greatly increased.

Drum speed on dryer is affected by:
- Belt diameter
- Belt alignment
- Belt condition

Be sure to check and replace belt if required.

BAFFLES:
Baffles inside dryer are positioned so that clothing is tossed around, increasing its exposure to heated air. Without baffles, clothing would not dry as quickly.

LINT TRAP AND DRUM SEALS:
For system to work efficiently:

1. FRONT AND REAR OF DRUM MUST BE PROPERLY SEALED:
If drum seal is defective, air can bypass heater box. This creates loss of negative pressure, reducing drying efficiency.

2. LINT TRAP MUST BE KEPT CLEAN:
If lint trap is clogged, negative pressure in burner box is reduced, and heat from burner flows out hole and is sensed by safety thermostat. End result of blocked lint screen is that air is not able to move freely, and drying time increases.

SERVICE:

ELECTRICAL SEQUENCE OF OPERATION:
Knowing sequence of operation for electrical start-up of dryer makes it easier to determine possible faults.

Typical sequence:
As soon as timer is turned on:
1. All circuits close
2. Circuit from timer to door switch is completed through door switch to timer motor and drive motor
3. Timer motor circuit is completed
4. Drive motor circuit is completed
5. Centrifugal switch is closed
6. Circuit from timer through thermostat to main coil valve is closed
7. Neutral from main coil valve is completed through limit switch and centrifugal switch
8. Burner is activated
9. Circuit from timer to panel and drum lights is closed

If this basic sequence does not occur, there is problem with dryer.

GENERAL ELECTRICAL TROUBLESHOOTING:
To locate general problem area:
1. Turn on dryer
2. Set temperature to high
3. Check power at burner
4. Test switches and loads

CHECK POWER TO BURNER:
- If there IS power to burner: Concentrate tests on burner
- If there is NO power to burner: Check operating switches in dryer circuit

THREE-POINT TEST:
Use three-point test to test switches and loads (requires good-quality multimeter):

OPEN SWITCH:
- Voltage reading across switch
- Voltage reading on inlet terminal to ground
- No voltage on outlet terminal to ground

CLOSED SWITCH:
- No voltage reading across switch
- Voltage reading on inlet terminal to ground
- Voltage reading on outlet terminal to ground

ON A LOAD:
- Voltage reading across load
- Voltage reading on hot terminal to ground
- No voltage reading on neutral terminal to ground

ON A LOAD THAT HAS LOST NEUTRAL:
- No voltage reading across load
- Voltage reading on hot terminal to ground
- Voltage reading to neutral terminal to ground

TROUBLESHOOTING BURNER IGNITION:

GLO-SIL AND SPARK-IGNITION SYSTEMS:
When line voltage is applied to Glo-sil igniter, it should heat up to operating temperature in 10 to 30 sec. Resistance across terminals of good igniter should be between 50 and 25Ω in Glo-sil coils.

Check Glo-sil ignition:
1. If there is power to burner, shut power off
2. Disconnect leads to burner
3. Use multimeter to check sensor switch and Glo-sil
4. Check for cracks in Glo-sil
5. If Glo-sil is fine, check radiant sensor for continuity

CAUTION: Never apply line voltage directly to sensor.

Can test igniter and motor of dryer using spark-ignition burner by applying direct power to igniter terminals.

SMELL OF GAS (Glo-sil and spark-ignition):
Possible causes and solutions:
- Welded igniter points → Sand down or replace
- Overfired burner → Check input
- Broken fan → Replace fan
- Bypassing valve → Replace valve
- Sensor opening before reaching 2200°F (1200°C) → Replace sensor

CONSTANT-PILOT BURNER:
Common faults:
- PILOT EXTINGUISHES: Drafts coming in (check outside vent flapper), dirty pilot (remove and clean), mercury switch not holding plunger up (replace)
- PILOT LIGHTS BUT NO HEAT: Door not staying closed (repair latch), blown fuse (replace and check cause), unplugged (plug in), plugged lint trap (clean), open limit switch (check blocked lint trap and exhaust vent), broken belt (replace), defective gas valve (replace), control set to "air" (set to "high")

GLOW-COIL IGNITION:
Transformer, warp switch, and warp switch heater are combined into one unit. If any one fails, all must be replaced as complete assembly.

To check unit:
1. Apply 120V to burner with gas supply turned off
2. Glow coil should glow for approximately 3.5 to 4 min and then go out as warp switch opens
3. Turn dryer off; after 10 to 15 min, warp-switch heater cools sufficiently to allow warp switch to close

Common faults:
- WARP SWITCH NOT OPENING: Defective warp switch heater (test with ohmmeter and replace unit)
- GLOW COIL NOT GLOWING: Corroded terminals (clean), defective transformer (measure voltage), defective pilot switch (replace), defective glow coil (replace)
- GLOW COIL GLOWING BUT NOT IGNITING GAS: Screen plugged with lint (clean), glow coil warped (reposition), defective glow coil (replace)
- NO PILOT FLAME: Pilot coil not energized (test pilot switch), defective pilot switch (replace)

TROUBLESHOOTING DRYER OPERATION:

MOTOR PROBLEMS:
- Motor runs but drum doesn't turn: Broken/loose belt, loose pulley, frozen drum shaft
- Motor hums but drum doesn't turn: Centrifugal switch contacts defective, switch mechanism stuck, motor start winding open, motor seized, drive components seized
- Motor doesn't stop: Incorrect wiring, grounded motor/wiring, faulty timer
- Motor doesn't start: Fuse blown, timer inoperative, motor inoperative, improper connection, door switch issue, door not closed properly
- Motor runs intermittently: Motor covered with lint, motor bearings tightening, dryer bearings tightening
- Motor runs louder than normal with burning odor: Centrifugal switch contacts failing to open, switch mechanism stuck

DRYER AND DRUM PROBLEMS:
- DRYER SMOKES: Lint accumulation (remove lint), burning wire insulation (check/correct short), overheated motor (check for lint buildup)
- CLOTHES DRYING TOO SLOWLY: Blocked lint trap/vent pipe (clean), defective drum seal (replace), excessively long vent pipe (shorten), temperature control thermostat set too low (check), defective heat selector switch (check), failed drum seal (replace), tripping safety thermostat (replace if trips on normal operation), fluctuating/insufficient house voltage (call power company)
- CLOTHES NOT DRYING ON AUTO-DRY: Timer advancing too soon (set for more time), control thermostat open to heat source (check thermostat)
- DRYER DOES NOT DRY PROPERLY: Dryer overloaded (instruct user), blower assembly plugged (remove lint), lint trap blocked (remove lint), door not sealing tightly (adjust or replace seal), thermostats malfunctioning (check), selector switch defective (check)
- DRUM TURNS BUT HEATER NOT ENERGIZED: Timer inoperative, selector switch faulty, terminal loose, thermostat inoperative, motor switch inoperative, wire broken in harness
- DRUM OPERATES NOISILY: Drum warped (replace), lower drum guide sticking (reposition/replace), idler pulley noisy (replace), belt squeaking (use bar soap on belt or replace), foreign objects in drum (remove), belt frayed (replace), drum support bearings worn (lubricate/replace), motor pulley loose (tighten), front/rear drum seals worn (replace), machine not level (level machine)

BURNER PROBLEMS:
- MAIN BURNER DOES NOT LIGHT: Safety thermostat wiring loose (check wiring or replace), temperature control thermostat inoperative (replace), motor centrifugal switch contacts defective (clean)
- MAIN BURNER DOES NOT OPERATE PROPERLY: Motor wiring loose or timer not working (check), defective door switch (replace), faulty temperature control thermostat (replace)

IMPORTANT: Motors on dryers have overload protector, which is similar to fuse. It protects motor from burning out if there is mechanical or electrical overload. When checking motor, check that overload protector has not failed. If protector has failed, motor needs to be replaced.

topics: Infrared grill benefits (less fuel, faster cooking, better taste)
Infrared burner heats to 1000°F (540°C) in 3 min
Lid, warming rack, cooking grates, flavorizer bars
Control panel, burner control knobs, igniter button
Safety when igniting (always open lid, wait for gas to clear)
Combustion process (venturi, primary air, air shutters)
Flame characteristics (light blue, dark blue, tips occasionally yellowish)
Smell of gas (leak detection and repair)
Burner not lighting (gas shut-off, hose bent/kinked)
Flare-ups or grease fires (excessive grease buildup)
Yellow or orange flame (blocked venturi or spider guard)
Cleaning venturi and burner tube with pipe cleaner
chapters.content:
Chapter 3 covers installation, operation, and servicing of gas-fired barbecues.

BURNERS:
Some barbecues have only one burner, while others have two burners placed side by side. Some barbecues also come with side burners.

INFRARED BURNER TECHNOLOGY:
Many barbecues today incorporate infrared burner technology used as rotisserie burners and, in some cases, as main burner. Infrared burner works by focusing flame of standard gas burner onto ceramic tile that has thousands of microscopic holes in it. This converts heat of flame into infrared energy, same energy you feel from sun on cold day. This heat is much higher and more intense than standard grill can produce.

MAIN BENEFITS OF INFRARED GRILL:
- Less fuel use
- Faster cooking time
- Better taste
- Simpler cleaning

Infrared burner heats to over 1000°F (540°C) in approximately 3 min. In amount of time traditional barbecue reaches normal cooking temperatures with all three burners turned to "high", single infrared gas grill burner can have cooked several steaks and be cleaned and cool enough to cover.

BRIQUETTES AND LAVA ROCK:
Many barbecues use ceramic briquettes or lava rocks. Gas flame heats surface of briquettes or lava rocks that, in turn, radiate heat to cook food. Take care not to have too many lava rocks or briquettes since heat being trapped between burner and rocks may cause premature burner burn-out and increase cooking times.

THE IGNITION SYSTEM:
Barbecues use crossover or piezo ignition system. When piezo button is pushed, it energizes igniter electrode inside gas-catcher ignition chamber. This creates spark that ignites gas. Barbecues can also be manually lit through match-light hole in front of cooking box.

CAUTION: Always have barbecue lid open before attempting ignition.

BARBECUE COMPONENTS:
Typical barbecue includes:
- Lid and lid handle
- Warm-up basket and warming rack
- Flavorizer bars (short and long)
- Cooking grates
- Work table and swing table assembly
- Frame connectors and wheel frame
- Wheels, casters, and wheel hubcaps
- Front panel and control panel
- Burner control knobs
- Igniter button and igniter assembly
- Gas catcher ignition chamber
- Manifold assembly and manifold bracket
- Burners (front, back, centre)
- Venturi tubes
- Spider stopper guards
- Crossover tube
- Catch pan and drip pans
- Thermometer
- Hose and tubing

OPERATION:

Each season, before barbecue is used, visual inspection must be made to ensure that all piping and tubing are sound and that there are no visible faults. Failure to do this could result in injury or death.

IGNITION SEQUENCE:

PIEZO IGNITION:
To light barbecue using piezo igniter system:
1. Ensure all burner control knobs are off
2. Open lid
3. Turn gas supply valve on
4. Turn burner control that is closest to igniter to "start" or "high"
5. Push piezo button several times so it clicks each time (each click creates spark)
6. Check through match-light hole in front of cooking box to see if front burner is lit
7. If burner is lit, turn on other burners (they light from flame of first burner)

MANUAL IGNITION:
To manually light barbecue:
1. Close all burner control valves
2. Open lid
3. Turn gas supply valve on
4. Light match and put it through match-light hole in front of cooking box
5. Turn front burner control knob to "start" or "high"
6. Check that burner is lit by looking through match-light hole
7. Once first burner is lit, turn on other burners

TO EXTINGUISH (both ignition systems):
- First, turn gas supply valve off
- Then turn each burner control knob off

SAFETY WHEN IGNITING:
- Always open lid before lighting barbecue
- If burner does not ignite, wait few minutes for gas to clear before trying again (gas may collect and explode)
- Never lean over barbecue or look through match-light hole when lighting barbecue

THE COMBUSTION PROCESS:
When burner control valve is open, gas flows into burner tube through venturi:
- Movement of gas through venturi reduces pressure in burner tube
- As result, primary air is sucked into tube through air shutters
- Primary air mixes with gas in burner tube and is ignited at burner head
- When air-gas mixture ignites, it draws in secondary air from around burner to complete combustion process

FLAME CHARACTERISTICS:
Good burner flame for barbecue:
- Light blue (outer)
- Dark blue (inner)
- Tips occasionally yellowish

ADJUSTING PRIMARY AIR:
Each burner on barbecue has air shutter that can be adjusted to allow more or less primary air into burner tube. For some models of burners, spider guard needs to be removed before they can be adjusted, while other types have shutters that move with screen in place.

SPIDER GUARDS:
Spider guards prevent spiders and other insects from nesting in burner tubes. Without guard and with nests in burner tubes, gas may flow out of air shutter, causing fire around shutter. If burners do not have spider guards, aftermarket types are available that can be added over venture tube air shutters.

One sign that indicates spider guard may need cleaning is cooking flame that appears to be yellow and lazy.

SERVICE:

TROUBLESHOOTING GAS BARBECUES:

SMELL OF GAS:
Possible leak → Shut off gas immediately, check for leaks, repair leak

LEAK DETECTED AT CONNECTION:
- Quick-disconnect coupling not seated fully → Remove coupling, check that coupling is clean, reconnect coupling
- Gas leak in connection → Tighten connection, perform leak test
- Gas leak in hose or control valves → Replace hose or control valves

FLAME FLASHBACK BENEATH CONTROL PANEL:
Venturi tube blocked → Remove burner and clean venturi tube. Use pipe cleaner or venturi brush to clean venturi.

SPARK IGNITION FAILURE:
Poor ground connections → Check and fix ground connections

BURNER NOT LIGHTING:
- Gas shut-off valve closed → Open gas shut-off valve
- Fuel hose bent or kinked → Straighten fuel hose
- Igniter wire(s) not connected → Connect burner electrode wires
- Igniter electrode misaligned on burner → Realign electrode
- Igniter malfunction → Manually light burner
- Venturi blocked → Remove burner and clean venturi
- Venturi not aligned with valve orifice → Realign venturi to orifice
- Orifice blocked → Remove burner, clean orifice with pin or fine wire

PREMATURE BURNER BURN-OUT:
Excessive lava rocks → Reduce number of lava rocks

HOT SPOTS ON COOKING SURFACE:
- Uneven briquette distribution → Spread briquettes evenly on grate
- Venturi blocked → Remove burner and clean venturi

FLARE-UPS OR GREASE FIRES:
- Excessive grease buildup on briquettes → Clean briquettes (remove cooking grid, turn briquettes over, light burner, allow self-clean, finish by placing briquettes in one layer)
- Dirty cooking surfaces or bottom tray → Clean thoroughly
- Excessive heat → Turn burner controls to lower setting or raise cooking grid

YELLOW OR ORANGE FLAME:
- Excessive yellow flame possibly caused by blocked venturi → Remove burner and clean venturi
- Spider stopper guard blocked → Clean spider stopper guard
- Burner ports blocked → Remove burner and clean with soft-bristle brush or scraper

FLAME LOW IN "HIGH" POSITION:
Fuel hose bent or kinked → Straighten fuel hose

INSIDE OF LID SEEMINGLY PEELING:
Grease buildup, not faulty paint → Clean with stiff-bristle brush or scraper

CLEANING VENTURI AND BURNER TUBE:
Clean venturi tubes using pipe cleaner or venturi brush to eliminate any blockages caused by spiders or insects.

IMPORTANT: When installing parts on barbecue, always refer to manufacturer instructions.

chapters.content:
Chapter 4 covers installation, operation, and servicing of gas-fired lamps.

INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:

Refer to Clause 7 of CSA B149.1 when installing gas lighting or lighting fixtures. All gas lamps must be installed according to manufacturer instructions, and installation must comply with Code. Once lamp has been installed, operating instructions must be left with user.

RATING PLATE AND SPECIFICATIONS:
All gas appliances must be fitted with rating plate that provides:
- Type of gas
- Btu rating
- Model number
- Serial number
- Clearances

Most gas lamps do not have appliance regulator and, therefore, operate at pressure supplied by piping system (usually 7 in w.c. for natural gas). In these cases, burner manifold pressure may not be noted on rating plate.

IMPORTANT: If gas lamp has been converted, this must be noted on rating plate.

Gas lamps vary considerably in design, and it is difficult to find standardized specifications. Manufacturers' specifications are, therefore, important to read during installations.

CLEARANCES:
Clearances for gas appliances are stated on rating plate of gaslight. CSA B149.1, Clause 7.31.3, also contains specific requirements for different types of lighting:

"Except where permitted by Clause 4.13.2, bracket or pendant fixture shall have following minimum clearances from combustible material:
a) Above — 18 in (450mm); and
b) All sides — 5 in (125mm)."

Main objective of clearances for gas lamps is to prevent globe from contacting combustible materials. Note that ignition temperatures vary for different materials. For example, paper on wallboard ignites at lower temperature than wood or plastic.

Therefore, locate lamp, taking into consideration temperature tolerance of surrounding materials.

Code allows reduction of clearance if:
- It is approved as being safe to do so by approved authority, and reduced clearance level is marked on rating plate; or
- Combustible material is protected, and reduced clearance is in accordance with Code

PIPING AND TUBING:
All piping and tubing used with gas lamps must meet code requirements. Gas lamp must be confirmed to be properly mounted and supported to avoid putting any pressure on piping supplying lamp.

Clause 7.31.2 of CSA B149.1 states: "A wall bracket fixture shall be firmly supported, and if of swing type, it shall be provided with stop to prevent contact of globe with combustible material."

COMPONENTS:

There are many different types of gas lamps, and components often vary from one lamp to next. Manufacturer assembly instructions normally list components of lamp.

VALVE ASSEMBLY:
Typical gas lamp valve assembly includes:
- Protective screen
- 1/4 in lamp valve in OFF position
- Valve assembly
- DC powered valve
- Threaded cap
- Brass hex nut
- Override button
- Slot above door opening (access slot)
- Valve stem
- Set screw

VENTURI ASSEMBLY:
Venturi assembly with electrode includes:
- Venturi assembly
- High voltage white wire to spark electrode's high voltage coil
- Green to ground
- Blue/red to DC powered gas valve
- Spark electrode

CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS:
Most gas lamps use same construction materials:

FRAME:
Usually made of iron, aluminum, brass, copper, or bronze. Brass and copper are commonly used for gas lamps due to their rust resistance.

BURNER:
Made of either copper or ceramic. Often enclosed by tempered glass globe to withstand temperature changes.

MANTLES:
Lamps are equipped with mantles, device for generating bright white light when heated by flame.

There are two basic types of mantles:
- Soft mantles (soft autoform mantles)
- Preformed hard mantles

INSTALLING THE MANTLE:

SOFT MANTLE:
Procedure for installing soft mantle:
1. Ensure lamp valve is closed and light has been off long enough to cool down
2. Remove old mantle
3. Loop tie-on strings at throat of mantle
4. Use fingers to enlarge throat so it fits over burner
5. Fit mantle over burner so that it seats in lower groove of burner nose
6. Shape mantle evenly
7. Pull ends of tie-on strings so that mantle and strings are seated securely in burner nose groove
8. Tie double knot in string and cut off ends
9. Hold lit match close to, but not touching, mantle. Mantle should smoulder as its protective coating burns off. Once done, mantle becomes form of chemical ash and must be handled carefully. It may break if touched.
10. Let mantle cool for few minutes after coating has burned off
11. Now, turn gas on and light mantle without touching it with match. On new installation, it may take while for mantle to burn because of air in gas line.
12. Turn gas on fully to allow mantle to burn to its proper shape. After about 5 min, adjust gas control for desired amount of light.

When gas light is burning properly, flame is bright white and has no visible outlines.

PREFORMED HARD MANTLE:
Installed as follows:
1. Ensure gas supply is turned off and light has been off long enough to cool
2. Remove old mantle
3. Take mantle out of its box and place throat over burner nose
4. Follow Steps 6 to 12 from procedure for soft mantles

GAS LAMP COVERS:
Gas lamp covers come in different forms. They serve decorative purpose as well as protecting flame from weather and other external effects. They also safely enclose burning flame.

Cover, including glass, should be able to resist sudden temperature changes that occur when lamp is switched on or off.

OPERATION:

Since there are many different types of gas lamps, it is important to read manufacturer instructions for specific lamps. These instructions must be left with user after lamp has been installed.

TYPES OF LAMPS:

INDOOR GAS LAMPS:
Indoor gas lamps serve both practical and decorative purposes. Make sure these lamps are used only in properly vented rooms. Carbon monoxide is formed if there is incomplete combustion. If room is not properly vented, there may be buildup of dangerous gases.

Area around lamp must also be kept free of combustible materials, including flammable vapours and liquids, such as gasoline.

Even though gas flame is small, it still requires primary air for combustion. Gas flows through venturi to burner. Movement of gas through venturi sucks in air through air ports.
- There should be no obstruction to flow of primary air
- If burner is dirty or has insects nesting in it, airflow is obstructed
- Burner must be kept clean

OUTDOOR GAS LAMPS:
Outdoor gas lamps are used mainly for decorative purposes. They can usually operate in all types of weather and are useful in event of power outage.
- With these lamps, there must be no obstruction to primary airflow
- Lamp must be properly vented
- There should be no combustible materials near lamp

PRINCIPLES OF GAS LAMP OPERATION:

Selection of lamp with or without mantle depends on intended use of lamp. Gas lamps without mantles give "flicker flame" and are intended purely for decorative purposes. For functional lighting purposes, lamp equipped with mantle is required.

GAS LAMPS WITH MANTLE:
In mantle-equipped gas lamp, mantle burns white hot and gives off light.

FLAME CHARACTERISTICS:
- BRIGHT WHITE WITH NO VISIBLE OUTLINES: Flame is burning properly
- NOT BRIGHT WHITE OR HAS VISIBLE OUTLINES: Airflow to gas may need adjustment
- YELLOW FLAME: Airflow should be increased
- POOR FLAME QUALITY: Cause may be broken mantle, in which case mantle must be replaced

ADJUSTING PRIMARY AIRFLOW:
Primary airflow is controlled by adjusting air-shutter rings near burner (check manufacturer instructions to determine exact location).
- Adjust air-shutter rings until optimal light is obtained
- Gas pressure may also need adjustment (check manufacturer instructions for correct pressure setting)

IGNITION:
There are two ways in which gas lamps are ignited:
1. By electrode that is operated manually with switch or automatically with photosensor; or
2. Manually using open flame, such as match

IN AUTOMATIC SYSTEMS:
Solar cell detects light falling below certain point and opens electronic circuit to electrode. It also opens gas valve.
- Electrode sparks until gas lamp is lit
- Photosensor detects when lamp is lit and stops electrode from sparking
- When light in area reaches certain level (such as at sunrise), solar cell closes gas valve and extinguishes lamp

SERVICE:

Because there are so many different types of gas lamps available, it is important to consult manufacturer instructions before installing or replacing any components.

Important that manufacturer procedures are followed. Otherwise, lamp may not work properly.

SERVICING AND TROUBLESHOOTING:
Before starting any repairs:
1. Turn off gas supply
2. Wait for lamp to cool
3. Remove and clean glass
4. Replace mantle if it is broken

GENERAL MAINTENANCE:
- Ensuring that venturi and all screens are clean and clear of insects
- Making sure solar cell is clean (if so equipped)
- Cleaning glass casings

At least once year, outdoor gas lamp should be properly cleaned and painted if necessary.

LEAK TESTING:
If there is smell of gas or if new gas lamp or new fittings have been installed to gas supply line, perform leak test with soap solution or leak detector.
- Check all joints and connections
- Tighten any connections that may be loose

CAUTION: Never use open flame to test for leaks.

FLAME IMPINGEMENT:
Burned metal on gas lamp indicates one of two situations:
- Flame that is too hot; or
- Flame impingement

Flame impingement means that flame is in contact with surface, causing flame to cool. When flame cools, it cannot burn all of gas so carbon or CO is produced.

To correct this problem, adjust:
- Air openings
- Gas pressure
- Or both

TROUBLESHOOTING ELECTRODE IGNITION SYSTEMS:

ELECTRODE DOES NOT BEGIN SPARKING WHEN IT GETS DARK:
- Check battery connection
- Check that battery voltage matches manufacturer specifications
- Check solar cell connection and polarization
- Check electrode wire and ground wire connections

ELECTRODE DOES NOT STOP SPARKING AFTER IGNITION:
- Check alignment of mantle over photosensor
- Check that photosensor is clean
- Check alignment of photosensor
- Check gas pressure

LAMP KEEPS BURNING AFTER IT GETS LIGHT:
- Check solar cell connection and polarization
- Check polarization of valve connection to circuit board

VALVE DOES NOT OPEN OR ALLOW OPERATION:
- Check polarization of valve connection to circuit board
- Check that battery voltage matches manufacturer specifications

VALVE OPENS, ELECTRODE SPARKS, BUT MANTLES DO NOT IGNITE:
- Check that gas supply line is properly bled of air
- Check that electrode is aligned with burner head
- Check alignment of mantle

AT NIGHT, LAMP IGNITES BUT THEN TURNS OFF:
- Check alignment of mantle over photosensor
- Check that photosensor is clean
- Check alignment of photosensor
- Check gas pressure

BATTERY VOLTAGE IS LOWER THAN MANUFACTURER SPECIFICATIONS:
- Check that solar panel is facing sun and allow battery to charge

documents.content:
CSA Unit 15 - Domestic 
Appliances 
Chapter 1                                       Gas 
Ranges: Installation and 
Servicing
Cooking with gas has always been the choice of professional chefs and has 
gained a similar reputation in the home. The instant heat and immediate cool-
down are features that electric units find difficult to compete with. Numerous 
styles of gas ranges, types of ignition systems, and temperature controls are 
used in today's product lineup. The gas technician/fitter must be aware of old 
as well as new technology that may be encountered when installing and 
servicing gas ranges.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Objectives
Describe Different Types of Gas Ranges
Understand the various types of gas ranges available 
in the market
Describe Installation Procedures
Learn proper piping and electrical connections for gas 
ranges
Describe Burners and Ignition Systems
Understand the different burner types and ignition 
mechanisms
Describe Oven Controls
Learn about calibration and testing of oven controls
Describe Operation of Gas Ranges
Understand how gas ranges function
Describe Servicing of Gas Ranges
Learn proper maintenance and repair procedures
Key Terminology
Term
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
Anti-tipping device
Device that prevents 
accidental tipping of a 
range
Appliance regulator
Used to reduce the gas 
supply pressure to the 
operating pressure of 
the appliance
Drill Manufacturer's 
Standard
DMS
Orifice
A hole or opening used 
primarily to control the 
direction and volume of 
gas flow into a burner
CSA Gas Trade Unit Red Seal
Occupational Skills
•
Performs safety-related 
functions
•
Maintains and uses tools and 
equipment
•
Plans and prepares for 
installation, service and 
maintenance
Gas Piping Preparation and 
Assembly
•
Fits tube and tubing for gas 
piping systems
•
Fits plastic pipe for gas piping 
systems
•
Fits steel pipe for gas piping 
systems
Venting and Air Supply Systems
•
Installs venting
•
Installs air supply system
•
Installs draft control systems
Red Seal Tasks (Continued)
Electrical Systems Controls
•
Selects and installs electronic components
•
Selects and installs electrical components
•
Installs automation and instrumentation control systems
Installation of Systems and Equipment
•
Installs gas-fired system piping and equipment
•
Installs gas-fired system components
•
Installs propane storage and handling systems
Testing and Commissioning
•
Tests gas-fired systems
•
Commissions gas-fired systems
Servicing Gas-fired Systems
•
Maintains gas-fired systems
•
Repairs gas-fired systems
•
Decommissions gas-fired systems
Types of Gas Ranges
Free-standing Ranges
Not built-in or permanently installed. Most residential service gas-fired 
ranges are 24 to 30 inches wide, free-standing units with an integral oven.
Built-in Ranges
Permanently installed as part of the kitchen cabinetry. A gas-fired wall oven 
is a separate built-in unit installed and operated independently from the 
drop-in countertop cooktop unit.
Gas and Electric Combination Units
Offer gas stove top burners with electric oven options.
Dual Fuel Units
Can run on propane or natural gas. The conversion is usually accomplished by 
means of an adjustable orifice.
Major Features of Gas Ranges
Self-cleaning Feature
An oven equipped with a self-cleaning feature incinerates the 
baked-on dirt in the oven by heating it to high temperature during a 
cleaning cycle.
For safety, the oven door locks when the cleaning cycle is selected 
and remains locked until the oven cools after the cleaning cycle ends.
Continuous Cleaning Feature
In a continuous cleaning oven, the dirt is baked off the oven surfaces 
on a continuous basis while food is cooking.
Broiler
Gas stoves formerly utilized the oven burner to broil food: the lower 
drawer was opened to allow the same oven burner to serve as a 
broiler burner.
Now, gas-fired ovens come with separate broiler units. The broiler is 
a special burner located in the top of the oven. Heat from the burner 
is directed downward towards the food for broiling.
Warming Drawer
Some gas-fired ovens also have warming drawers, which maintain 
cooked food at the desired serving temperature.
Heat Transfer Methods
Convection
Transfer of heat by heat currents
•
Natural convection: warm air rises, 
cool air descends
•
Forced convection: fan circulates 
heat evenly
Conduction
Transfer of heat through direct contact
•
Example: pot on range top burner 
heated through direct contact with 
flame
Radiation
Transfer of heat by means of heat rays
•
Example: overhead broiler burner
Convection Methods
Natural Convection Oven
Warm air rises and cool air descends in the process of 
natural convection. In a standard, natural convection oven, 
the hottest area is at the top of the oven and the coolest is at 
the bottom no matter where the burner is located.
Thermostats located in the oven can control the burner on-
off cycle within a certain temperature range, but the 
temperature may vary as much as 50°F from one area of the 
oven to another. This makes it difficult to cook food evenly.
Forced Convection Oven
In a forced convection oven, a fan circulates the heat from 
the burner evenly throughout the oven.
The circulating heat cooks food faster and more evenly than 
a natural convection oven.
Installation Requirements
Manufacturer's 
Specifications
Found on the model and 
serial number identification 
plate (rating plate) 
attached to the appliance at 
the factory.
Applicable Codes
All range installations must 
conform to the 
requirements of applicable 
building, gas and electrical 
codes.
Installation Instructions
Detailed instructions provided by the manufacturer for proper 
installation.
Before installing a gas-fired range, review this information to ensure the 
installation will conform to the necessary requirements.
Manufacturer's Specifications
Btu/h (kW) Rating
Input rating of the 
appliance in Btu/h (or 
kW) is stamped on the 
rating plate.
Approvals
Approvals by regulating 
authorities and 
agencies.
Operating Voltage 
and Current
Electrical requirements 
for the range.
Operating Pressure
Required gas pressure 
for proper operation.
Input Rating and Approvals
Input Rating
The input rating of the appliance in Btu/h (or kW) is 
stamped on the rating plate. The rating plate specifications 
allow the appliance installer to determine the correct pipe or 
tubing size for the service and to set the burner inputs 
correctly.
Approvals
Gas industry and governmental regulatory agencies must 
approve all gas appliances before the manufacturer can sell 
them. Regulatory authorities recognize the service of third-
party certification organizations and provide the approval by 
insisting that gas appliances receive certification from a 
recognized certification organization.
The official logo, symbol, or seal that indicates the 
certification of the appliance appears on the appliance's 
rating plate. The certification symbols that must appear on 
the rating plate of a gas appliance sold in Canada include 
those of CSA Group. Local provinces may recognize other 
agencies.
Operating Voltage and Pressure
Operating Voltage and Current
The range must only be connected to an electrical circuit 
that conforms to the operating voltage and current rating 
specified on the identification plate. Although older gas 
stoves with few options for operation could function with 
just a gas supply hookup, most gas stoves require a 110 V 
supply outlet to power clocks, ignition sources, 
programmable features, and oven lighting.
Operating Pressure
Gas supply pressure is normally higher than that required for 
burner operation. An appliance pressure regulator is used to 
reduce the supply pressure to the manifold pressure 
required at the burner and maintain it at that level.
It is important to maintain the correct manifold pressure 
setting in order to avoid service problems and hazardous 
conditions such as delayed ignition, sooting, flashback, 
extinction pop, damage to components, poor operating 
efficiency, and limit cycling.
Gas Pressure Requirements
7
Natural Gas Inlet
Typical inlet pressure in inches w.c. (1.5 kPa)
11
Propane Inlet
Typical inlet pressure in inches w.c. (2.7 kPa)
3.5-5
Natural Gas Manifold
Typical outlet pressure in inches w.c. (0.9-1.25 kPa)
10
Propane Manifold
Typical outlet pressure in inches w.c. (2.5 kPa)
The regulator is usually pre-adjusted for use with the type of gas specified on the rating plate and for a specific outlet pressure. Many 
ranges come with a regulator that is adjustable for use with propane or natural gas.
Code Requirements
Electrical Connections
Most gas ranges require electricity to power clocks, timers, 
and other control devices. The electrical connection is usually 
120 V 60 Hz, two-wire, with ground. The minimum size and 
type of wire that can be used for a 120 V, 15 A indoor appliance 
is No.14 AWG NMD-90.
Piping Connections
The Code requirements for gas range piping and tubing 
connections can be found in CSA B149.1, which will be 
referred to as the Code.
Rigid piping or flexible connectors may be used to connect 
ranges to the gas supply. Metal (flexible) connectors must be 
installed in accordance with Code requirements.
Electrical Connection Requirements
1
Proper Connections
All electrical connections between 
an appliance and the building 
wiring must comply with 
applicable electrical codes. 
Connection of all electrical devices 
associated with the appliance 
must follow the manufacturer's 
wiring diagram.
2
Power Supply Cord
A range must be connected to the 
electrical circuit receptacle by 
means of an approved power 
supply cord with a three-prong 
grounding plug. Extension cords 
may not be used.
3
Grounding
Under no circumstances should 
the grounding prong of a power 
supply cord be removed or 
replaced with a two-prong plug or 
adapter.
Flexible Connector Requirements
Protection
Connectors must be protected from potential damage.
No Passing Through Barrier

CSA Unit 15 - Domestic Appliances Test (120 Questions)
Gas Ranges: Installation and Servicing
What is the typical natural gas manifold operating pressure at the burner for residential installations? a) 7 inches w.c. (1.75 kPa) b) 3.5-5 inches w.c. (0.9-1.25 kPa) c) 11 inches w.c. (2.7 kPa) d) 10 inches w.c. (2.5 kPa)
What is the typical propane manifold operating pressure? a) 3.5 inches w.c. (0.9 kPa) b) 7 inches w.c. (1.75 kPa) c) 10 inches w.c. (2.5 kPa) d) 11 inches w.c. (2.7 kPa)
What device prevents accidental tipping of a range? a) Spider guard b) Anti-tipping device c) Appliance regulator d) Drill Manufacturer's Standard
What is the minimum electrical wire size for a 120V, 15A indoor appliance? a) No. 12 AWG NMD-90 b) No. 14 AWG NMD-90 c) No. 16 AWG NMD-90 d) No. 10 AWG NMD-90
According to the Code, what is the minimum clearance for a range's back and sides from combustible surfaces if not specified by the manufacturer? a) 100 mm b) 125 mm c) 150 mm d) 200 mm
What type of metal shield is required for combustible cabinets next to a range cooking surface? a) 26 MSG metal shield b) 28 MSG metal shield c) 30 MSG metal shield d) 32 MSG metal shield
For zero clearance ranges, what is the minimum space required between the back of the range and a combustible surface? a) 0.5 inch (12 mm) b) 1 inch (25 mm) c) 1.5 inches (38 mm) d) 2 inches (50 mm)
What voltage should be measured between line and neutral conductors at a range receptacle? a) 110V ±10% b) 115V ±10% c) 120V ±10% d) 125V ±10%
What voltage should be measured between neutral and ground conductors at a range receptacle? a) 0V b) 12V c) 24V d) 120V
What does DMS stand for in orifice sizing? a) Drill Manufacturing Standard b) Drill Manufacturer's Standard c) Direct Manufacturing System d) Direct Measurement Standard
What is the smallest orifice size in the DMS system? a) No. 1 b) No. 60 c) No. 80 d) No. 100
What is the largest orifice size in the DMS system? a) A b) Z c) No. 1 d) No. 80
What is the typical natural gas supply pressure at the outlet of the gas meter? a) 3.5 inches w.c. (0.9 kPa) b) 5 inches w.c. (1.25 kPa) c) 7 inches w.c. (1.75 kPa) d) 11 inches w.c. (2.74 kPa)
What is the typical propane inlet pressure? a) 7 inches w.c. (1.75 kPa) b) 10 inches w.c. (2.5 kPa) c) 11 inches w.c. (2.74 kPa) d) 15 inches w.c. (3.7 kPa)
Which type of burner has a series of thin slots that distribute the flame? a) Ribbon port burner b) Slotted port burner c) Sealed burner d) Standard burner
What is the operating temperature of a hot surface igniter? a) 1800°F (982°C) b) 2000°F (1093°C) c) 2200°F (1204°C) d) 2400°F (1316°C)
What happens when a self-cleaning cycle is selected on an oven? a) The oven door unlocks b) The oven door locks c) The burner turns off d) The temperature decreases
What temperature does a self-cleaning oven reach during the cleaning cycle? a) 750°F (400°C) b) 850°F (454°C) c) 950°F (510°C) d) 1050°F (566°C)
In a forced convection oven, what circulates the heat? a) Natural air currents b) A fan c) The burner flame d) The oven door
What is the maximum temperature difference acceptable between set point and actual oven temperature during calibration? a) 5°F (3°C) b) 10°F (5°C) c) 15°F (8°C) d) 20°F (11°C)
What is the typical amperage draw for a Carborundum (round) ignitor? a) 2.0 to 2.5 amps b) 2.5 to 3.0 amps c) 3.2 to 3.6 amps d) 3.5 to 4.0 amps
What is the typical amperage draw for a Norton (flat) ignitor? a) 2.0 to 2.5 amps b) 2.5 to 3.0 amps c) 3.2 to 3.6 amps d) 3.5 to 4.0 amps
What voltage drop across the safety valve indicates it will open in a hot surface igniter system? a) 2V b) 3V c) 4V d) 5V

Gas Clothes Dryers: Installation, Operation, and Maintenance
What are the clearance requirements for domestic dryers from combustible materials at the back and sides? a) 4 inches (100 mm) b) 6 inches (150 mm) c) 8 inches (200 mm) d) 12 inches (300 mm)
What is the front clearance requirement for domestic dryers? a) 18 inches (450 mm) b) 20 inches (500 mm) c) 24 inches (600 mm) d) 30 inches (750 mm)

What is the typical inlet pressure for a dryer operating on propane? a) 6 inches w.c. (1.5 kPa) b) 8 inches w.c. (2.0 kPa) c) 10 inches w.c. (2.5 kPa) d) 12 inches w.c. (3.0 kPa)
What is the balancing pressure typically set at for a dryer regulator? a) 2.5 inches w.c. (0.6 kPa) b) 3.5 inches w.c. (0.9 kPa) c) 4.5 inches w.c. (1.1 kPa) d) 5.5 inches w.c. (1.4 kPa)
What is the minimum diameter for a dryer exhaust vent? a) 3 inches (76 mm) b) 4 inches (102 mm) c) 5 inches (127 mm) d) 6 inches (152 mm)
What is the minimum distance the exhaust hood should be from the ground? a) 8 inches (200 mm) b) 10 inches (250 mm) c) 12 inches (300 mm) d) 15 inches (375 mm)
What is the termination distance required from regulator vents or fresh air intakes for domestic dryers? a) 0.5 m b) 1 m c) 2 m d) 3 m
What is the termination distance required from fresh air intakes for commercial dryers? a) 1 m b) 2 m c) 3 m d) 4 m
What should be used to connect moisture exhaust duct joints? a) Sheet metal screws b) Duct tape c) Wire ties d) Clamps only
What is the maximum length of rigid metal vent with no elbows? a) 54 ft (16.5 m) b) 64 ft (19.5 m) c) 74 ft (22.5 m) d) 84 ft (25.6 m)
What is the maximum length of flexible metal vent with no elbows? a) 26 ft (7.9 m) b) 36 ft (11.0 m) c) 46 ft (14.0 m) d) 56 ft (17.1 m)
At what speed should a dryer drum rotate? a) 35-40 rpm b) 42-45 rpm c) 47-50 rpm d) 52-55 rpm
What is the operating temperature of a Glo-sil igniter? a) 2000°F (1093°C) b) 2100°F (1149°C) c) 2200°F (1204°C) d) 2300°F (1260°C)
How long should a Glo-sil igniter take to reach operating temperature? a) 5-15 seconds b) 10-20 seconds c) 15-30 seconds d) 20-35 seconds
What should the resistance across a good Glo-sil igniter be? a) 25-50 Ω b) 50-125 Ω c) 125-200 Ω d) 200-300 Ω
What is the typical high limit switch setting for dryer temperature controls? a) 160-190°F (71-88°C) b) 170-200°F (77-93°C) c) 190-250°F (88-121°C) d) 200-280°F (93-138°C)
What must a dryer do if the door is opened during operation? a) Continue running b) Sound an alarm c) Stop the drum and burner d) Only stop the drum
What happens to the warp switch in a glow coil system after 3-4 minutes? a) It closes b) It opens c) It resets automatically d) It continues operating normally
What is the normal motor speed when the centrifugal switch closes in a dryer? a) 1000 rpm b) 1100 rpm c) 1200 rpm d) 1300 rpm
Barbecues
What is the maximum length of hose that can be used for barbecue connections? a) 8 ft (2.4 m) b) 10 ft (3 m) c) 12 ft (3.7 m) d) 15 ft (4.6 m)
Where must the shut-off valve for a barbecue be installed? a) At the barbecue b) Inside the house c) Immediately upstream of the hose d) At the gas meter
What is the minimum distance between shut-off valve handles on independent connections? a) 4 inches (100 mm) b) 6 inches (150 mm) c) 8 inches (200 mm) d) 10 inches (250 mm)
What temperature should hoses be protected from exceeding? a) 100°F (38°C) b) 125°F (52°C) c) 150°F (66°C) d) 175°F (79°C)
What prevents spiders and other insects from nesting in burner tubes? a) Air shutter b) Spider guard c) Venturi tube d) Orifice
What is the primary purpose of a quick disconnect fitting? a) To replace a manual shut-off valve b) To provide convenient connection/disconnection c) To regulate gas pressure d) To prevent gas leaks
What should be done before disconnecting a barbecue with a quick disconnect? a) Light all burners b) Close the shut-off valve c) Remove the propane tank d) Clean the fitting
What is the ideal barbecue flame color? a) Completely yellow b) Blue with slight yellow tips c) Completely blue d) Orange with blue base
At what temperature can an infrared burner heat in approximately three minutes? a) 800°F (427°C) b) 900°F (482°C) c) 1000°F (538°C) d) 1100°F (593°C)
What should always be done before lighting a barbecue? a) Remove the cooking grates b) Open the lid c) Close all vents d) Remove the propane tank
What is the correct procedure for extinguishing a barbecue? a) Turn off burner controls first, then gas supply b) Turn off gas supply first, then burner controls c) Turn off both simultaneously d) Close the lid first
What can cause flame flashback beneath the control panel? a) Low gas pressure b) Blocked venturi tube c) Faulty igniter d) Loose connections
Gas Lamps: Installation, Components, Operation, and Servicing
What is the minimum clearance above a bracket or pendant gas lamp fixture from combustible material? a) 12 in (300 mm) b) 15 in (375 mm) c) 18 in (450 mm) d) 24 in (600 mm)
What is the minimum clearance on all sides of a gas lamp from combustible material? a) 3 in (75 mm) b) 4 in (100 mm) c) 5 in (125 mm) d) 6 in (150 mm)
What pressure do most gas lamps without regulators operate at for natural gas? a) 5 inches w.c. b) 6 inches w.c. c) 7 inches w.c. d) 8 inches w.c.
What device generates bright white light when heated by a flame in a gas lamp? a) Venturi b) Gas mantle c) Electrode d) Photosensor
What are the two basic types of mantles? a) Hard and soft b) Soft and preformed hard c) Natural an

DRYER Symbols
Dryer Heat Thermostat
Dryer High Limit Switch
Dryer Gas Solenoid
Dryer Timer Motor
Dryer Centrifugal Switch
Dryer Pilot Switch

Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
1 
Unit 15 – Chapter 01: Ranges 
 
1. What information found on the rating plate needed to determine the correct pipe size and 
check individual burner gas flow? 
a) Input rating 
b) Manifold pressure  
c) Operating voltage 
d) Minimum supply pressure 
 
2. The appliance regulator is usually pre-adjusted for use with the type of gas specified on the 
rating plate and for a specific outlet pressure. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
3. How are gas ranges typically connected to the electrical power supply? 
a) A three phase 4 wire cable 
b) Hard wired into a junction box with armoured cable 
c) A power supply cord with a 120 VAC three-prong grounded plug 
d) A power supply cord with a 240 VAC three-prong grounded plug 
 
4. The appliance regulator on a range is adjusted by changing the position of a simple 
converter fitting. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
5. How is the final connection to the gas supply manifold done to provide for movement of the 
gas range in order to clean behind it? 
a) A maximum 0.6 m long flexible metal gas connector 
b) A maximum 1.0 m long flexible metal gas connector  
c) A maximum 2.0 m long flexible metal gas connector  
d) A maximum 3.0 m long flexible metal gas connector
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
2 
6. To determine the required clearance to combustibles for a range, refer to the gas code over 
the manufacturer’s instructions or the rating plate. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
7. What is the allowable clearance to combustibles for a range certified for zero clearance 
(without additional protection)? 
a) 600mm above, 25 mm at the back 
b) 750mm above, 25 mm at the back 
c) 600mm above, 150 mm at the back 
d) 750mm above, 150 mm at the back 
 
8. If you have three certified metal flexible connectors of different lengths, they will all have 
the same gas flow capacity. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
9. When checking the manifold pressure, there must be gas flowing to properly read and 
adjust pressures. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
10. How does a sealed gas burner design maintain clean burner ports? 
a) Burner cap collects debris 
b) Flash tube burns of debris. 
c) Integrated drip pan gets removed and cleaned  
d) Burner cap deflects debris away from the flame 
 
11. How is the oven temperature recalibrated on mechanical style gas ovens that do not have 
adjustable thermostats? 
a) Adjust the temperature setting knob 
b) Change the gas orifices 
c) Adjust the manifold pressure 
d) Factory setting cannot be changed
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
3 
12. How long should a gas range operate before adjusting the oven temperature calibration? 
a) 1 minute 
b) 5 minutes 
c) 15 minutes 
d) 30 minutes 
 
13. A properly adjusted burner flame should extend high enough so that the inner blue cone of 
the flame is above the burner ring or grate, and able to touch the cooking vessel. 
a) True 
b) False

Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
1 
Unit 15 – Chapter 02: Clothes dryers 
 
1. If there are no manufacturer's rating plate clearances, what are the allowable code 
clearances to combustibles from the top, back and sides of a domestic gas dryer? 
a) 50 mm 
b) 150 mm 
c) 450 mm 
d) 600 mm 
 
2. What is the maximum length of a metal connector used to connect a gas dryer? 
a) A maximum 0.6 m long flexible metal gas connector 
b) A maximum 1.0 m long flexible metal gas connector  
c) A maximum 2.0 m long flexible metal gas connector  
d) A maximum 3.0 m long flexible metal gas connector 
 
3. What should be used to connect dryer moisture exhaust duct joints? 
a) Foil duct tape 
b) Electrical tape 
c) Cloth mesh duct tape 
d) Three evenly spaced sheet metal screws 
 
4. The moisture exhaust duct can be connected to another gas appliance vent connector to 
create a common vent. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
5. How far above ground level should the exhaust hood terminate? 
a) 200 mm 
b) 300mm 
c) 500 mm 
d) 1000 mm
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
2 
6. What determines the maximum length of the exhaust system? 
a) Type of exhaust hood 
b) Type of vent material 
c) Number of elbows 
d) All of the choices  
 
7. What will cause a gas dryer to keep running after its door is opened? 
a) Faulty door switch 
b) Faulty booster coil 
c) Faulty holding coil 
d) Defective centrifugal switch 
 
8. What problem would a defective drum seal cause? 
a) Dryer smokes 
b) Clothes drying too slowly 
c) Drum operates, but noisily 
d) Main burner does not light 
 
9. What is the minimum exhaust vent diameter for a gas dryer? 
a) 3 inch  
b) 4 inch 
c) 5 inch 
d) 6 inch 
 
10. What problem would be caused by the dryer not being level? 
a) Dryer smokes 
b) Clothes drying too slowly 
c) Drum operates, but noisily 
d) Main burner does not light

Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
1 
Unit 15 – Chapter 03: Barbecues 
 
1. Most barbecues can be used on Propane or natural gas without any modifications. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
2. A shut-off valve is not necessary when using a quick disconnect device? 
a) True 
b) False 
 
3. Barbecues equipped with a piezo ignition can be match-lit? 
a) True 
b) False 
 
4. Aftermarket spider guard can be installed onto burner tubes. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
5. During the lighting of a barbecue, the lid must be closed. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
6. What is the maximum length of a barbeque connecting hose? 
a) 0.6 m 
b) 2 m 
c) 3 m 
d) 4.6 m

Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
1 
Unit 15 – Chapter 04: Lamps 
 
1. Soft mantles are more durable than hard mantles due to their flexibility. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
2. The purpose of the venturi assembly is to generate bright white light when heated by the 
flame. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
3. Indoor gas lamps should only be used in well ventilated rooms. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
4. Before starting any repairs, you should turn off the gas supply and allow the glass to cool. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
5. How often should a gas lamp be cleaned? 
a) Weekly 
b) Monthly 
c) Annually 
d) Bi-annually

Review for Module 14
Domestic Appliances
Sections of moisture exhaust duct on a dryer are held together using:
Locking bands
Duct tape.
Metal screws.
Wire mesh.
A moisture exhaust duct on a residential dryer and a service regulator must be a minimum distance of:
36 inches apart
12 inches apart
48 inches apart
24 inches apart
Gas dryers are required to be vented:
Through a hepa filter
To the outdoors
To a filtered container outdoors
To  a heat recovery ventilation unit
Dryer exhaust ducts must not be screwed together.
True
False
Dryer exhaust ducts must joined using duct tape.
True
False
A pendant type gas lamp requires a side clearance from combustibles of:
12 inches
0 inches
5 inches
18 inches
The minimum top clearance from combustibles for a domestic gas range is?
24 inches
30 inches
36 inches
48 inches
At what temperature does a self-cleaning range activate the door lock switch?
212 deg. F.
450 deg. F.
650 deg. F.
900 deg. F.
Identify the following electrical dryer symbol
Dryer heat thermostat
Dryer gas solenoid
Dryer centrifugal switch
Dryer high limit switch
Dryer pilot switch

Dryer heat thermostat

Dryer pilot switch

Dryer heat thermostat
Dryer gas solenoid
Dryer centrifugal switch
Dryer high limit switch
Dryer pilot switch
The purpose of a mantle on a gas lamp is to:
Change a blue flame to a luminous flame
Act as a manifold device
Protect the lighter mechanism
Ignite the air/gas mixture
The maximum length of a corrugated metal connector for a gas range is:
5 feet
8 feet
6 feet
24 inches
What function does the minimum burner flame have on a direct acting modulating oven control?
It prevents rapid cooling of the oven temperature
It prevents excess oven temperature fluctuation
It makes perfect pies
It maintains a minimum oven temperature
The spark on a spark ignition dryer is de-energized by:
Thermocouple
A main burner switch
A flame switch
A thermo-meter
A dryer motor switches from start to run mode utilizing what?
Capacitor
Centrifugal switch
Low limit switch
Thermostat
What is the maximum length of an approved hose for a gas fired barbecue?
Two feet.
Any length.
Thirty Feet.
For standing pilot, three feet, for piezo ignited, six Feet.
A range burner with a control valve located at the rear of the range shall not be installed unless:
The  valve is readily accessible
The valve is readily inaccessible
The valve is rated for excessive temperatures
The valve is of the lubricated plug type
When a flexible metal connector is used to connect the domestic appliance to rigid piping, where shall a shutoff valve be installed in the piping system?
Immediately upstream of the flexible  connector
Immediately downstream of the flexible  connector
Immediately downstream of the appliance regulator
A shut off valve s not required when using a flexible  connector
During the lighting of a barbecue what position should the lid be in?
Closed
Open
Either A or B
None of the above
Each season before a barbecue is used, what must be done?
Lines must be isolated and pressure tested - 15 minutes at 15 psig
A visual inspection must be conducted to ensure that all piping and tubing is sound and that there are no visible faults
A visual inspection must be conducted to ensure that burner primary air openings are free of insects or debris
Both A and C
None of the above
How often should a gas lamp be cleaned
Every 6 months
Every year
Every two years
None of the above
What could cause insufficient drying in a domestic clothes dryer, even if the lint screen is kept clean?
Blocked vent
Defective drum seal
Blocked air flow in dryer
Dryer firing below rated input
All of the above
Adding an excessive number of lava rocks or briquettes to a barbeque:
Can cause food to burn quickly
May undercook food
May cause premature burner burn-out
None of the above.

Dryer heat thermostat
Dryer gas solenoid
Dryer timer motor
Dryer high limit switch
Dryer pilot switch
Identify the following electrical dryer symbol.
Dryer heat thermostat
Dryer gas solenoid
Dryer centrifugal switch
Dryer high limit switch
Dryer pilot switch
Identify the following electrical dryer symbol.
Dryer heat thermostat
Dryer gas solenoid
Dryer centrifugal switch
Dryer high limit switch
Dryer pilot switch
How are barbeques lit?
Piezo ignition system
Hot surface ignition system
Match-light
A or C
None of the above
How long should a gas range operate before calibrating the oven temperature control?
15-20 minutes
5-10
50 minutes
30-45 minutes
None of the above
A free-standing residential gas-fired range is:
Built-into the counter space
Not built-in or permanently installed
Dropped into the counter space
None of the above
